STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 18, 2020
Carol Kehoe
Ingham County DHHS
P. O. Box 30088
Lansing, MI 48909
RE: License #: CP330201190
Ingham County DHHS
5303 S Cedar Street
Lansing, MI 48909
Dear Ms. Kehoe:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
10/15/20. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules are also violations of the MISEP and
policy. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
235 Grand, Ste 1305
P.O. Box 30650
Lansing, MI 48909
(517) 899-6024
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP330201190
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Carol Kehoe, Administrator
Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Ingham County DHHS
Facility Address: 5303 S Cedar Street
Lansing, MI 48909
Facility Telephone #: (517) 887-9791
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1991
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 10/05/2020

since last inspection 1 1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
1 of 8 foster home files reviewed did not indicate why the home was not in
compliance with the rules.
1 of 8 foster home files reviewed did not indicate if the home was in compliance with
all the rules on the 3080.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
2 of 8 foster care files reviewed did not have timely dentals completed.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
4

(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside in
the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
medical care.
2 of 8 foster care files did not have placement outlines signed by the caregiver
indicating they received this information at placement.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal with a CAP accepted
on 1/18/19 and the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP accepted on 12/12/19.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(a) Dates, types, and places of agency contacts and persons
contacted.
1 of 4 Initial Service Plan’s reviewed did not include all the contacts.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(a) Dates, types, and places of agency contacts and persons
contacted.
2 of 22 Updated Service Plan’s reviewed did not include all the contacts.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
5

2 of 8 foster care files reviewed had missing visits by the foster care worker:
 1 had a missing visit in March of 2020
 1 had two missing visits in November and December of 2019
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker
and the youth in independent living at least once each month at
a youth's place of residence.
1 of 3 Independent Living files reviewed had one missing visit in January of 2020.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to
meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous
expenses.
2 of 3 Independent living case files reviewed did not have quarterly budgets
completed.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 12/12/19.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the service plan
must address the living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
6

1 of 3 Independent Living case files reviewed did not have treatment plans that were
updated with current information.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
1 of 3 Independent Living case files reviewed did not have quarterly contracts
completed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.54 Psychotropic Medication, Informed Consent (Commitment
90).
DHHS shall ensure that informed consent is obtained and
documented in writing in connection with each psychotropic
medication prescribed to a child in DHHS custody.
1 of 8 foster care youth did not have informed consents for psychotropic medication.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 12/12/19.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
7

4 of 8 open foster care files did not have timely Action Summaries completed.
1 of 4 closed foster care files did not have a case closing Action Summary.
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE PLACEMENT HOME STUDY
The DHS-3130A, Relative Placement Home Study, is a
comprehensive home assessment that considers multiple
domains in a prospective caregiver's life. The DHS-3130A,
Relative Placement Home Study, allows caseworkers to identify
strengths and barriers that may impact a child's placement.
1 of 2 relative home studies that were reviewed did not include all necessary
information needed to assess the placements needs.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Medical Passport Receipt Documentation
Receipt of the medical passport by the required parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
4 of 8 foster care files reviewed did not have quarterly medical passport with
signatures from the caregiver.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal with a CAP accepted
on 1/18/19 and the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP accepted on 12/12/19.
FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval - USP
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required assessments
(FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and approved by the
foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
8

4 of 26 Foster Care Service Plans reviewed did not have timely supervisor approval.
 1 report was approved 1 day late
 1 report was approved 5 days late
 1 report was approved 7 days late
 1 report was approved 13 days late
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal with a CAP accepted
on 1/18/19 and the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP accepted on 12/12/19.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
over 14-Years Old
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP.
8 of 26 service plans reviewed did not have a parents or youth signature.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
Caregiver
The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates
that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
5 of 26 service plans reviewed did not have the required caregiver signature.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2018 Renewal with a CAP accepted
on 1/18/19 and the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP accepted on 12/12/19.
FOM 722-06H CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)/ GUARDIAN(S)
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact with
the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s residence.
9

1 of 8 foster care files did not have the required visits with the parent in his/her
home.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 12/12/19.
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact.
7 or 8 foster care files reviewed did not have face to face contacts entered timely.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Interim Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 12/12/19.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting.
Type Time Frame
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 14 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
5 of 8 foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed prior to completion of
the service plans.
3 of 8 foster care files reviewed did not have the FTM documentation uploaded.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Indicate in annual and renewal evaluations that the foster family posted and
practiced emergency procedures.
 Signed and dated 3706 should be uploaded into MiSACWIS.
 Proofread reports and contacts to ensure all information is accurate.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require consultation at this time.
10

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were not any incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. A Special Evaluation was initiated when it was reported that in 2017 Foster
Home A “beat” one of the foster youth when she would not go to sleep. Foster Home
A would not cooperate with the investigation and meet with the licensing worker so
they were found in violation of R 400.9201 Foster parent qualification, R 400.9404
Behavior management, and R 400.9207 Subsequent evaluations. The agency is
seeking revocation of Foster Home A’s license.
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during this
licensing period.
VII. ANALYST FINDINGS
The analyst completed 3 home visits to foster homes and 3 visits to relative homes.
The analyst did not note any safety concerns during her visits. All service concerns
were discussed during the entrance conference that included the analyst, the field
consultant, and agency management.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
11/17/20
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 18, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
